description.narrative:
The Project is expected to: (i) increase the supply of wheat to African millers in the destination countries to produce wheat products; (ii) increase the supply of animal feed (soya bean, corn) to destination countries; (iii) increase technical support from the Group to millers to improve food safety and quality; and (iv) increase (in-kind) financing to millers to ensure continuity in commodity trading.
To measure progress against this outcome, IFC will track the: (i) volume of products supplied to customers; and (ii) number of customers reached.
The Project is expected to have catalytic effect of stimulating industry-wide best practices in grain trade financing, grain sourcing and processing, and facilitating food quality and safety improvements, moving the sector toward greater competitiveness from domination by large players to more participation by mid-sized players.
To measure progress against this outcome, IFC will track the number of private sector banks providing support to the Company (which should increase or at least remain stable).

The proposed investment is a US$20m IFC unfunded participation under a Risk Sharing Facility (RSF) in an up to US$60m uncommitted transaction secured revolving trade finance Facility for 3-years with annual renewals with Banque Internationale de Commerce-BRED (Suisse) SA (BIC-BRED or the Bank) for Agro Companies International (Agro Companies or the Group). The RSF will finance Agro Companies grain trading working capital needs, mainly (i) floating cargoes secured by the bills of lading (BLs), (ii) storage in warehouse at destination with Stock and Monitoring Agreement (SMA), and (iii) receivables on African buyers mainly covered by prime credit insurers. It will be processed under the Global Warehouse Finance Program (GWFP) with delegated authority from the Board.
